stems.text: The following table compares the heights of students in a class at a primary school. One student was absent on the day the heights were recorded.

questions.text: What was the average height of the students whose heights were recorded?
questions.explanation: Add the heights up and divide by 7

stems.text: What was Tim’s height if the average height of the students in the class was 118cm?

text: If Tim is taller than Liam but smaller than May, what is the range of heights of students in the class?
options: Can’t tell (as Liam’s height is not provided)

text: If Tim’s height is 5cm greater than the average height of the 8 students, what is Tim’s height?
explanation: (Sum of heights + x)/8 = x – 5; x = 122.1

text: The table below illustrates the number of paying customers and the total number of items purchased (in thousands) at a large retailer from January to December 2019. Suppose that the average cost of items purchased at the shopping centre was $21.47 every month of 2019.

questions.text: What was the average number of items purchased from the retailer each month for 2019 (in thousands)?
questions.explanation: Add the entries up (in the total items purchased column) and divide by 12

text: If the average number of items purchased each month increased by 20% from 2018 to 2019, how many more items were purchased from the retailer in 2019 than 2018 (in thousands)?
What was the average amount spent by each customer on items in January and February 2019?

All of the money generated by the retailer comes from the items sold. If 30% of the money generated is spent on tax, 30% is expenses and the rest is profit, what was the retailer’s average monthly profit for 2019 (to the nearest $1000)?

The exam scores of students from a year 10 class in mathematics, physics and chemistry are recorded below. If a student scores less than 50 in an exam, they are asked to re-sit their exam and their original mark is changed to their re-sit mark.

questions.text: What was the average chemistry exam score in the class (not considering re-sits)?
questions.explanation: Sum of all the chemistry scores/10 = 81.1

text: How much higher was the average mathematics score than the average physics score (not considering re-sits)?
explanation: Sum of all the mathematics scores/10 – sum of all the physics scores/10 = 5.3

text: If the individual(s) re-sitting their chemistry exam score(s) twice as high when re-sitting, by how much will the average chemistry score increase?
After adjusting the physics exam marks (after re-sits), the average physics mark increased to 75.9. What was the average final mark of those who re-sat the physics exam?
explanation: 75.9 * 10 – sum of scores of those who passed = 122; 122/2 = 61

text: Ryan, a long-distance runner, went on 6 separate runs in preparation for an upcoming competition.He gradually increased the time he spent on each run and the distance. Times are expressed as hours: minutes: seconds and all distances are in miles.

questions.text: What was the average distance of the 5 runs (with distance indicated) in miles?

text: If the average distance of the 6 runs was 15% lower than the average distance of the 5 runs (with distance indicated), what was the distance of the first run?
If the average speed of the first run was 6 miles per hour, what was the distance of the first run?
If the average speed of the first run was 6 miles per hour, which run did Ryan travel at the fastest average speed?
explanation: Can attempt to calculate average speeds (distance/time) or use a method of inspection and estimation (preferable to maximise time efficiency)

text: The following table illustrates the amount spent and earned by Chris, a high school student working shifts at the local bakery, over the course of one and a half weeks. He does not have to pay tax on any amount earned.

questions.text: What was the average amount spent by Chris (per day) over the days given (to the nearest dollar)?

text: If Chris’ hourly rates are twice as high on weekends than weekdays, how much longer did he work on the first Friday compared to Saturday?

Suppose that Chris transfers all the money he earns (minus the money he spends) to his bank account every day. If he spends more money than he earns on a given day, he must withdraw the gap from his bank account. What is the average amount Chris transfers/ withdraws from his account every day over the period given?
explanation: (Sum of money earnt – sum of money spent)/11 = 1.91

text: Chris decides to save up for a $5000 car. Over the course of a year, he earns the same amount (daily) as the average amount in the table above and reduces his spending to 20% of his earnings. How long (to the nearest 10 days) will it take Chris to save up the $5000 for the car?

Over the year, there are 7 different assessment pieces for chemistry. The assessments each have a different weighting in contributing to the student’s overall score. The results of one student in chemistry is given below.

questions.text: What was the average mark achieved by the student in the assessments (not the weighted average)?

text: What was the student’s overall score (i.e/ the weighted average mark)?
explanation: Weightage/100 * mark for assignment 1 + Weightage/100 * mark for assignment 2… = 76.6

text: How much higher did the student have to score on the exam in order to achieve an overall score of 80?
If the weightage of the exam was halved and quiz 2 tripled, what would be the percentage increase in the student’s overall score?
explanation: Weightage/100 * mark for assignment 1 + Weightage/100 * mark for assignment 2… (using the weightage for the exam as 20 and quiz 2 as 30)= ~80; (80 – 76.6)/76.6 * 100 = 4.4

text: Erin, Lisa, Molly, Joseph and Brian competitively played 3 games of bowling and their scores were recorded. The scores are displayed on the table below. The individual with the highest average score wins the 1st prize of $60, the individual with the second average score wins the 2nd prize of $30 and the individual with the third highest average score wins the 3rd prize of $20.

questions.text: Who won the bowling competition?
questions.explanation: Calculate the averages for each to determine who had the highest average (sum the 3 games and divide by 3) or determine the answer by inspection. Joseph had the highest average of 105

text: How much more money did Lisa win than Brian?
explanation: Lisa came second ($30) and Brian was not in the top 3

text: In the case of a draw for a prize, those who are drawn are required to have another game. Which 2 competitors
explanation: Both Erin and Molly had an average of: (76 + 96 + 120)/3 = 97.3

text: Jill also joins in the competition and achieves the same bowling score in 3 consecutive games. What percentage increase in her 3rd throw will yield a 10% increase in her average score?

The following table displays the hours worked per week and the hourly rate of 11 friends. A tax rate of 10% is applied to the first $500 of money generated each week and a tax rate of 20% applies to any money in excess of $500 generated in a week. Whatever is left over after tax is the individual’s income.

questions.text: What was the average number of hours worked per week by the 11 friends?

text: What was the average amount of money generated (per week) by the 3 individuals with the lowest weekly income?
explanation: Stanley, Jenny and Karen; (22 * 20 + 20 * 20 + 25 * 15)/3 = 405

text: What average tax rate does Olivia have to pay on her weekly income?
If Penelope and Violet both decided to reduce their number of working hours (per week) by 25%, what would be the effect on the range of incomes of the group of 11 friends (per week)?
explanation: Ralph then becomes the highest earner; 45 * 35 = 1575; 40 * 40 – 1575 = 25; 25 * 0.8 = 20

text: The following table compares the average maximum and minimum temperatures (from January to December 2019) in a city. All temperatures are given in Fahrenheit. To convert from Fahrenheit to degrees Celsius, subtract 32 and multiply by 5/9.

questions.text: What percentage of the 12 months in 2019 had an average minimum temperature below freezing (0 degrees Celsius)?
questions.explanation: 5 months showed an average minimum temperature of below 32F

text: What was the average difference in maximum and minimum temperatures in the city over the 12 months of 2019 (to the nearest degrees Fahrenheit)?
explanation: (Sum of high – sum of low)/12 = 20

text: Due to the effects of global warming, the average maximum temperature in January has been increasing by 10% (year-on-year) since 2015. What was the average maximum January temperature from 2015 to 2019 inclusive (in degrees Fahrenheit)?

Suppose that the minimum/maximum temperatures are recorded every day of a month and the values are averaged to give the values in the table above. In February 2019, a minimum temperature of 5 degrees Fahrenheit was recorded on 3 separate occasions. If these 3 minimums were not included in the calculations of an average, how much would the calculated average minimum temperature in February increase by (in degrees Fahrenheit)?

The table below compares the number of customer visits and the number of orders placed on cars at a car dealership each month in 2018. To place an order on a car, the customer must visit the car dealership, place an order and pay for the car on the same day as the visit. Each car is sold by the dealership for $5000 and costs the dealership $1170 to source. The dealership’s revenue on each car is the difference between the sale price and the cost associated with sourcing the car. The dealership’s only source of revenue is selling cars.

questions.text: What was the average number of customer visits to the dealership (each month) for 2018?

text: What was the car dealership’s average monthly revenue for the first quarter of 2018 (i.e from January to March) to the nearest $1000?
In which quarter of 2018 did the car dealership have the highest average monthly revenue?
explanation: The most cars were sold from July to September

text: 30% of the dealership’s monthly revenue is paid to the tax office and the remaining money is paid to the staff. If there were 60 staff members in November 2018 (as opposed to 70 staff members in December 2018) how much more money was paid to each staff member, on average, in November compared to December?

Jim started a company that sells computers. The following table compares the number of computer sales each month for the first half of 2018 (by Jim’s company) with 2 different models used to predict the number of computer sales each month (forecast 1 and 2). Jim is trying to decide which model is more accurate in predicting his company’s monthly computer sales.

questions.text: What was the average number of monthly sales for the first half of 2018?

text: What percentage higher was the average monthly sales prediction for forecast 2 than the average monthly sales prediction for forecast 1?
explanation: ((Sum of forecast 2) – (Sum of forecast 1))/(Sum of forecast 1)

text: In what month was the number of computer sales equal to the average value of forecasts 1 and 2?
explanation: The average of the forecasts equalled: (43 + 35)/2 = 39

text: For July 2018, the sales prediction for forecast 1 was 6% higher than forecast 2.  The actual sales value (for July 2018) was 1% higher than the average of forecast 1 and 2. If the sales prediction for forecast 1 was 1 greater than the actual number of sales, what was the actual number of sales for July (to the nearest whole number)?
explanation: The best way to attempt this is through a trial an error approach of each option to see which leads closest to the prediction for forecast 1 being 1 greater than the actual number of sales

text: The following table compares the number of monthly influenza deaths from 1917 to 1921 in the state of Indiana.

questions.text: What was the average number of influenza deaths (per month) in Indiana in 1921?
questions.explanation: Sum of the column/number of entries = 26

text: In which year was the average number of influenza deaths (per month) in Indiana the highest?
explanation: Can attempt to calculate the averages or just inspect the data to save time

text: If 500 individuals died immediately (within a day) of contracting influenza in Indiana in 1919 and the immediate death rate remained consistent throughout the year, roughly how many individuals immediately died of influenza in Indiana in the first quarter of 1919?
explanation: 500/total deaths in Indiana in 1919 = 0.17; 0.17 * sum of deaths from Jan – March = 414

text: If the percentage decrease in the average number of influenza deaths (per month) in Indiana from 1920 to 1921 equalled that of 1921 to 1922, how many individuals died of influenza per month (on average) in 1922 in Indiana?
explanation: (Average number of influenza deaths in 1920 – average number of influenza deaths in 1921)/(average number of influenza deaths in 1920) * (average number of influenza deaths in 1921) = 3.5

text: A group of individuals (from a variety of different age groups) were asked to choose their favourite leisure activity from a list of 6 different activities. All those surveyed made a selection and the results were tabulated.

questions.text: What was the average number of respondents (per age group above) who chose ‘socialising with 4 or less people’ as their favourite leisure activity?
questions.explanation: Sum of all figures in the row/7 = 214

text: If X teens changed their selection from individual exercise to group exercise, the average number of respondents (per age group above) who chose ‘group exercise/sport’ as their favourite leisure activity would increase by approximately 7.1%. What is the value of X?
explanation: (Total number of respondents who chose ‘group exercise/sport’) * 1.071 – Total number of respondents who chose ‘group exercise/sport’ = 85

text: What leisure activity had the highest average number of respondents per age group?
explanation: Don’t summate each row, just use inspection; tv is TV/videos is the only category with more than 1,000 individuals in an age range

text: Suppose that (on average) 20% of those aged below 50 (whose favourite leisure activity is individual exercise) regularly swim, while 45% of those aged above 50 (whose favourite leisure activity is individual exercise) regularly swim. What percentage of respondents (whose favourite leisure activity is individual exercise) regularly swim?
The following 2 tables compare the sales (in millions of Euros) of coffee and bananas in 5 different European countries in 1999 and 2004.

questions.text: If 1 euro is equal to 0.91 pounds, what was the average sales of coffee in the 5 countries in 1999 (in millions of pounds)?

text: What was the percentage increase in the total number of banana sales in the 5 countries from 1999 to 2004?
explanation: (Total number of banana sales in 2004 - total number of banana sales in 1999)/(total number of banana sales in 1999) * 100 = 186

text: What percentage reduction in the sales of coffee in the UK in 2004 would yield a 20% decrease in the average sales of coffee in the 5 countries in 2004?

In order to increase the sales of coffee in Denmark, the unit price of coffee is reduced by 10%. As a result, the number (not value) of sales of coffee increases by 20% from 2004 to 2005. If the value of sales is equal to the number of sales multiplied by the unit price of coffee, what would be the value of coffee sales in Denmark in 2005?
2 separate surveys were conducted in 1985 and 2011 to determine the average distance travelled per person per year by mode of travel. The results are displayed below.

questions.text: What was the percentage increase in the total distance travelled per person per year from 1985 to 2000?
questions.explanation: (total distance travelled in 2000 – total distance travelled in 1985)/(total distance travelled in 2000) * 100 = 36.6

text: Suppose that all cars require petrol. In 1985 petrol cost $1 per litre while in 2000 petrol cost $1.50 per litre. Each litre of petrol allows a car to travel to travel for 2.5 miles. How much more money was spent on average (per person per year) on petrol (for cars) in 2000 than 1985?
If 1.6km=1 mile and walking for 1km burns 100 calories of energy, how many calories of energy did the average person burn per month (on average) from walking alone in 1985?

Suppose that the ‘other’ modes of travel consist only of boat and tram travel and, on average individuals travel 3 times as much distance on boats than trams (each year). How much more did individuals travel (on average) by boat in 2000 than 1985 (in miles)?

The following table illustrates the 6 different types of families within country X and the number/ proportion of people from each family types living in poverty. Assume that every citizen of country X fits into one of those family types and the population of country X is 17 million.

questions.text: On average, out of every 400 citizens of country X, how many are single aged people?

text: Approximately what percentage of citizens of country X poverty?
explanation: Sum of third column/17 million * 100 = 10.8

text: If there are 2 million households in country X consisting of couples with children, how many people (on average) occupy each of these households?

Each individual living in poverty from country X claims $300, $400 or $500 weekly from the governments. 40% of those living in poverty claim $500 weekly, while twice as many individuals claim $400 weekly than $300 weekly. How much does country X pay monthly (on average) to each individual living in poverty?
The table below depicts the quantities of fruit sold annually (in thousands of tonnes) in 5 different countries.

questions.text: What is the average quantity of peaches sold in each of the 5 countries annually (in tonnes)?

text: What percentage higher is the average quantity of Cherries sold in each of the 5 countries annually than the average quantity of oranges sold in each of the 5 countries annually?
explanation: (Average of cherries – average of oranges)/(average of cherries) * 100 = 55%

text: If 25% of the ‘others’ category consists of mandarins, how many more mandarins are sold than bananas each month (on average) in Australia?
If each ton of grapes is sold for 36% more than each ton of bananas, what percentage more is generated from the sale of grapes in the UK than bananas in Italy?
The number of sales of a product within a number of stores across the cities of America, along with the unit price of the product, are illustrated in the table below.

questions.text: What is the average quantity of the product sold in each of the stores listed?

text: What would be the percentage increase in the average money generated by these stores from the sale of this product if the unit price was increased by 15%?
explanation: A 15% increase is maintained

text: If X number more products were sold at both of the Chicago stores, the average money generated by the sale of the products in the Chicago stores would be exactly three-quarters that of the St Louis stores. What is the value of X?
What is the minimum percentage increase required in the unit price of the product in the Seattle stores such that they generate the same money (on average) as the Los Angeles stores?

A survey was carried out in a primary school class to determine the number of hours spent watching TV (by students) every week. All students were required to give their answer as a whole number and all responses were between 1 and 10. The number of students are displayed on the y-axis and the number of hours are displayed on the x-axis.

questions.text: How many students watch an average of more than 40 minutes of TV every day?
questions.explanation: 40 * 7/60=4.7; number of students watching 5 or more hours is 30

text: Experts recommend that children watch no more than an average of half an hour of TV daily. How many students in this class are not adhering to this guideline?
explanation: 0.5 * 7 = 3.5; number of students watching 4 or more hours is 30

text: John, Jeff and Jill are in this class. John averages half the time watching TV each day than Jeff while Jeff averages two-thirds the time watching TV each day than Jill. If Jill spends 1 hour watching TV each day (on average), how many classmates spend the same amount of time watching TV (each week to the nearest half hour) as John?
explanation: Jeff – 40 minutes; John – 20 minutes per day = 2 hrs 20 per week; 5 in the 2 hr category

text: What is the average time spent by each student in this class watching TV each week (in hours)?
explanation: Multiply each time by the number of students watching for that time and sum together, then divide by the number of students total

text: Mary is looking to buy a new house. She is researching houses on sale in her desired suburb and taking note of the amenities in each house; in particular, the number of bathrooms in each house. The following table depicts the number of bathrooms and the number of houses (on sale in the suburb) with the indicated number of bathrooms.

questions.text: If the average price of the houses with one bathroom is $250K and the two most expensive houses with one bedroom (each worth $1 million) are sold, by how much will the average house price of the houses with one bathroom decrease (to the nearest thousand dollars)?

text: What will be the increase in the average number of bathrooms in each of the houses if the number of houses with 3 bathrooms was doubled?
explanation: The final category doesn’t give us a definite number of bathrooms

text: If twice as many of the houses have 5 bathrooms than 7 bathrooms (more than 1), what is the average number of bathrooms in each of the houses?
explanation: Multiply the number of bathrooms by the frequency and add them, divide by the total frequency

text: Mary buys a house for $856K. She takes out a $700K loan and pays $156K from her savings. In order to pay off the loan, Mary plans to pay an average of $51K per year for 14 years. What percentage more would Mary be paying this way in comparison to paying the $856K directly from her savings?
The following graph shows the amount of environmental waste created and recycled from 2000 to 2013 in tonnes.

questions.text: What is the closest average of the total waste generated from 2000, 2005 and 2007?

text: If the total waste generated in 2009 was 3.15 million tonnes, what is the average of total waste generated from 2007-2010?
explanation: No statistic is given for 2008

text: Which pairs of years had the same average of trashed waste?
explanation: 2009/2010 and 2011/2012; average of ~3.25 million tonnes

text: In which year was the average of trashed and recycled waste equal to 1.5 million?
explanation: Total waste would be 1.5 * 2 =3; This is seen in 2007

text: The following graph displays the preferred snack choices of students at Hillary’s high school, for both boys and girls.

questions.text: What is the closest average number of boys who preferred snacks starting with a P or V?

text: Which of the following snack choice has the highest preference numbers as an average of girls and boys?
explanation: The highest of the following is fruit (being ~185); The highest overall would be chips

text: Which snack choice has the lowest preference numbers as an average of boys and girls?
explanation: Vegetable only has an average of ~155; This can be answered via inspection to save time

text: What is the difference between the average number of boys who preferred popcorn and chocolate bars compared to the average number of girls who preferred popcorn and candy, to the closest value?

The following graph shows the rates of unemployment for adults in the Nordic countries for men and women. The total population of Denmark is 10 million, Finland is 15 million, Iceland is 20 million, Norway is 25 million and Sweden is 30 million. Assume there are the same number of men and women in each country

questions.text: What is the average unemployment rate amongst men in Denmark and Finland collectively?

text: What is the average difference between the number of unemployed women and men of the two countries, Denmark and Iceland?
What is the average difference in male and female unemployment rates across all 5 countries?
explanation: Sum of male unemployment rates/5 – sum of female unemployment rates/5 = 0.62

text: If the average unemployment rate was 5% in Norway last year, by how much has the current average unemployment rate for in Norway changed?
The following graph shows the number of sneakers sold this month in Chadstone Shopping Centre.

questions.text: What is the average number of sneakers sold this month at Chadstone Shopping Centre?

text: If the average number of sneakers sold this month at Chadstone Shopping Centre was 25 sneakers, including a new Bomber sneaker that is not accounted for in the graph, how many Bomber sneakers were sold this month at Chadstone Shopping Centre?
What is the average number of sneakers sold this month at Chadstone Shopping Centre, of those which sold over 15 sneakers?
If the number of New Balance sneakers sold was actually 28, but how much does the average of sneakers sold at Chadstone Shopping Centre change?
The following chart displays the trends in overweight and obese people from 1997-2007 in America vs the state of Wisconsin, as a percentage of the total population.

questions.text: If the population of the nation in 2003 and 2001 was 200 million and 150 million respectively, what is the average number of obese people in the nation between 2001 and 2003 on the graph (not including 2002), to the nearest million?
questions.explanation:
200 million * 0.12 = 24 million
150 million * 0.105 = 15.75 million
(24 million + 15.57 million)/2 = 19.875 million = 20 million to the nearest million

text: What is the average number of obese and overweight people combined, between the nation and Wisconsin in 2007, to the nearest ten? The population of the nation in 2007 was 300 million, and in Wisconsin 56 million.
If the average percentage of overweight people in the nation over the years, 1999, 2001, 2003, 2005 and 2007 was 14.78%, what was the percentage of overweight people in the nation in 1999?
explanation: 14.78 * 5 – percentage overweight in 2001, 2003, 2005 and 2007 = 14.5

text: If the average number of overweight and obese people in the nation in 2003 and 2007 was 100 million, and there were 150 million overweight and obese people people in the nation in 2003, how many overweight and obese people were in the nation in 2007?
The following table shows the transmission of light through a beaker of water with varying salt concentrations over 5 trials.

questions.text: What is the average transmittance across all 5 trials at a salt concentration of 12%, to 2 decimal places?

text: What is the average difference between the transmittance recordings between trials of the same number at salt concentrations of 6% and 9%?
explanation: Difference of each trial (higher value – lower value) added together and divided by 5 will give 5.2460%

text: If the average transmittance across all salt concentrations for Trial 2 was 100%, what is the transmittance for Trial 2 at a salt concentration of 3%?
explanation: 100 * 5 – the sum of the values of the four other trials = 92.82

text: Which salt concentration out of the following had the lowest average transmittance across Trials 1, 3, 4 and 5?
explanation: You can calculate the average transmittance by summing the trials and dividing the value by 5 for all the different salt concentrations. Or you can attempt to arrive at 9% via inspection

text: The following table below shows the GDP of 5 countries from 1998 to 2003. The values are in billions of dollars.

questions.text: What was average GDP for China from 1998 to 2003, in billions of dollars to the nearest billion?

text: If the exchange rate from dollars to rupees (Indian currency) is 150 (1 dollar is 150 rupees), what is the average GDP for India between 2001 and 2003 in billions of rupees?
Of these 5 countries, what was the average GDP in 1999?
explanation: Sum of column/5 = 4,235.8

text: Of the following years, which year had the lowest average GDP across the 5 countries?
explanation: Can attempt to compare average GDPs for the years by calculating: Sum of column/5; Or, you could seek to answer the this via inspection

text: The following table shows the different prices in dollars and mileage in kilometers for two different models of Chevrolet cars.

questions.text: What is the average price for Corvette models in dollars?

text: What is the difference between the average mileage of Corvette models and Malibu models?
explanation: Sum of Corvette milages/4 – sum of Malibu milages/4 = 8,910.33

text: If the average price in dollars for Malibu models is $34,676.83, what is the value of the black space in the table, to the nearest dollar?
explanation: 34,676.83 * 6 – the 5 existing Malibu prices = 28,846

text: What is the average mileage between the most expensive Malibu model and the cheapest Corvette model (excluding the blank value)?

The table below shows the different times it took for 3 different hamsters to complete a maze designed by some scientists. Each of the hamsters had 10 attempts at completing the maze and all of them completed it.

questions.text: What was the average time taken by hamster 1 to complete the maze in the first 6 trials, rounded to the nearest second?

text: What was the average time for all 3 hamsters in the 7th attempt?
If a 4th hamster was included in the table, what would its time to complete the maze have been for attempt 4 if the average time for all 4 hamsters on attempt 4 was 37.5 seconds?
What is the difference in the average time taken to the complete the maze across all 10 attempts for hamster 3 and hamster 2?
explanation: Sum of column for hamster 3/10 – sum of column for hamster 2/10  = 3.1; if you get a negative answer, take the magnitude of that as your answer

text: The table below shows the different times it took for 3 different mice to complete a maze designed by some scientists. Each of the mice had 10 attempts at completing the maze and all of them completed it. Some of the values are missing.

questions.text: What was the average time taken to complete the maze on attempt 5 by all 3 mice?

text: How much longer/shorter did mouse 3 take to complete the maze on the 8th attempt than mouse 2?
If the average time of all 3 mice on attempt 7 is 24, how long did mouse 2 take in attempt 7?
What was the average time of mouse 3 to complete the maze across all its 10 attempts?
explanation: Sum of mouse 3 column/10 = 26.2
